basics.name: Clark Wakeland
basics.summary: Satellite systems engineer with a focus on GNC and mission operations. Background in computer science and embedded systems.

work.name: Lockheed Martin
work.summary: Designed and wrote test procedures in Python for the spacecraft electrical systems. Collaborated with GNC team to develop hardware-in-the-loop simulations for the spacecraft attitude control system.

volunteer.summary: Served as technical mentor for high school students in the Code Quest Academy program. Helped students develop an understanding of fundamental programming concepts, data structures, and algorithms.

courses: Control Systems, Spacecraft Dynamics, Orbital Mechanics, Michigan Swimming and Diving
Space Systems Design Lab (SSDL), Laboratory for Intelligent Decision and Autonomous Robotics (LIDAR), Georgia Tech Swimming and Diving

awards.title: CSC Academic All-American
awards.summary: Awarded to student-athletes exhibiting outstanding academic and athletic achievement.

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.
